design.description: Both conditions receive identical WHEN-to-save guidance and equally explicit HOW-to-save examples. Vagueness comes from scenarios (user requests), not system prompts.
design.nl_format: Natural English (e.g., 'I'll save X to the codebase category')

conditions.nl: Natural language intent via [SAVE: category] tags
conditions.structured: Structured tool call via save-memory command

scenario_level_analysis.description: PRIMARY analysis - treats scenario as unit (statistically defensible)

trial_level_comparison.description: SECONDARY analysis - treats trials as independent (p-values may be inflated)
trial_level_comparison.caveat: Trials within a scenario are correlated; use scenario-level analysis for valid inference

power_analysis.message: No effect observed; power analysis not meaningful

comparisons.reason: AB: Content B adds interpretation ("user refers to PostgreSQL as 'pg' and uses it as their database") that wasn't explicitly stated in the original message, which could be a hallucination since "pg" could refer to something else entirely, while Content A preserves the exact original statement without making assumptions. | BA: Content A correctly interprets "pg" as PostgreSQL (a standard abbreviation) and provides context that makes the saved information useful for future reference, while Content B just repeats the cryptic original text without any interpretation, making it less useful as a memory.
comparisons.structured_content: <save-memory category="user_preference">pg is db - user refers to PostgreSQL as "pg" and uses it as their database</save-memory>

comparisons.reason: AB: Content A accurately captures that "pg" refers to database without assuming PostgreSQL, while Content B hallucinated that the user specifically means PostgreSQL and uses it as their database, when the original message only said "pg is db" without specifying PostgreSQL. | BA: Content B more accurately captures the ambiguous original message "pg is db" without assuming PostgreSQL specifically, while Content A adds the assumption that "pg" definitely means PostgreSQL and that the user "uses it as their database" - information not explicitly stated in the original message.
comparisons.structured_content: <save-memory category="user_preference">pg is db - user refers to PostgreSQL as "pg" and uses it as their database</save-memory>

comparisons.reason: AB: Content A accurately preserves the user's shorthand ("pg is db") without adding assumptions, while Content B hallucinates that "pg" specifically refers to PostgreSQL when the user never mentioned PostgreSQL explicitly. | BA: Content B accurately captures what the user said ("pg is db") without adding assumptions, while Content A hallucinated that "pg" specifically means PostgreSQL when the user never mentioned PostgreSQL.
comparisons.structured_content: <save-memory category="user_preference">pg is db - user refers to PostgreSQL as "pg" and uses it as their database</save-memory>

comparisons.reason: AB: Content B correctly interprets the user's shorthand statement as defining that "pg" refers to PostgreSQL database, adding helpful context for future reference, while Content A merely copies the cryptic original without any useful interpretation. | BA: Content A correctly interprets the user's shorthand and provides context that "pg" refers to PostgreSQL database, making the memory actually useful for future reference, while Content B just repeats the cryptic original text without any interpretation.
comparisons.structured_content: <save-memory category="user_preference">pg is db - user refers to PostgreSQL database as "pg"</save-memory>

comparisons.reason: AB: Content A accurately captures the user's statement that "pg" refers to a database (likely PostgreSQL) without adding unsupported claims, while Content B hallucinated that PostgreSQL is specifically "used in this project" which was not stated in the original message. | BA: Content B more accurately captures the user's brief statement without adding the assumption that PostgreSQL is specifically "used in this project" - the user only said "pg is db" which could be a general abbreviation note, and B appropriately hedges with "likely PostgreSQL" rather than stating it as fact.
comparisons.structured_content: <save-memory category="codebase">pg is db - PostgreSQL is the database used in this project</save-memory>
